subtitle: The inaugural issue of the New Thinking Allowed magazine
was just released on March 1st.
You can download a free PDF copy from the New Thinking Allowed
Foundation website.
That's newthinkingallowed.org.
You can even order a printed copy from nta-magazine.magcloud.com.
Thinking Allowed, conversations on the
leading edge of knowledge and discovery with
psychologist Jeffrey Mishlove.
Hello and welcome.
I'm Emmy Vadnais, co-host with Jeffrey Mishlove.
Our topic today is Art and the Invisible World of Parapsychology.
My guest is Shannon Taggart, who is an artist
and author of the book Seance, that documents
historical and artistic photos of spiritualism.
Shannon has been interviewed a previous time
on New Thinking Allowed with Jeffrey Mishlove,
and I'm going to link to that interview in the upper right corner of your screen.
It's called A Photographer Among the Spirits.
Shannon is joining me today in person as we're both located in St. Paul, Minnesota.
Now I'll switch over to that video.
Welcome Shannon.
It's such a joy to have you with me in person today on New Thinking Allowed.
Yes, thank you for having me.
It's great to be here.
We both know that art and parapsychology is a really big topic, and you have spent the
last 20 or so years photographing spiritualists.
So we're going to be talking more about the last like maybe 100 years or so of modern
and maybe contemporary art.
Yes.
Through my project on spiritualism and photographing
spiritualism, I never saw the two topics related.
But the further I worked and the longer my project became, I realized how inextricably
linked photography and spiritualism are.
They both were invented around the same time of the 18th century.
There's locational synchronicities.
Photography freezes time, and we can look at the past with it.
Spiritualists try to speak with people who are no longer here.
My book kind of focuses on a lot of these interconnections between the two.
But then through the work, I realized how
parapsychology, the material culture of parapsychology,
meaning the images and the devices and the documentation that has happened through the
practice of studying the mind and the invisible
forces at work in parapsychology, that it
created this very unique material culture that I see very much as its own visionary
art.
And I'm very interested in kind of like the material that has been discarded or thrown
away by parapsychology, meaning that, you know, the images that were supposed to be
used as proof, you know, and such.
I'm kind of thinking that art, the artist has a real ability to say something using
these materials.
How does one photograph or document through art the invisible world?
So that's a topic that I was immediately confronted
with when I tried to photograph mediumship
and spiritualists.
I constantly was questioning, how do you photograph invisible things?
How do you make a picture about a visible body speaking to an invisible presence?
And my technique that I developed over time
was using playing with time and playing with
mistakes or things that I didn't intend to
give me a language to speak for the invisible.
And at first, when I was making exposures, you know, longer exposures, it was due out
of necessity because I was in a lot of dark room situations.
But I was having these uncanny synchronicities
between the invisible experience and what
was coming through in my camera.
And both skeptics and believers were confused
by my process, like, you know, spiritualists,
all of their art is an endeavor with evidence
and trying to prove that, you know, they're
seeking evidence of their proof of contact or,
you know, there's a lot of focus on merging
religion and science and kind of proving that
we can have contact with the dead and contact
with the other side.
And then the skeptics would say, this doesn't
mean anything, it's just a blurry picture.
But I was having these strong synchronicities
with some of the pictures and also I started
to realize that one of the primary hallmarks
of a paranormal experience is that time and
space becomes irrelevant or different or changed.
And I thought about how, you know, when we
photograph marathon runners, we really abstract
time to a very short window of time that our eyes never see.
And so, you know, thinking about the space-time
continuum and how we perceive time in a straight
line, it doesn't really work in the way that we perceive it.
You know, this is getting very conceptual,
but I really thought that the synchronicities
I was getting were speaking to some truth about the experience.
And what was the truth you found?
That these experiences have a complicated
relationship with truth, just as photography
does.
And one of the biggest compliments I've received
from my work and the photographs published
in my book was many mediums have contacted me and expressed thanks that I was able to
speak to the reality of their experience in a way that is not done in words or not done
in scientific study.
And I started to think about, you know, the
truth of the laboratory, the repeatable truth
of the laboratory is very different than
the truth of the artist or the truth of art.
And that there's an emotional truth in art that we acknowledge.
And so, how this other type of truth could
play into parapsychology, and is there another
truth in these artifacts that people have
disregarded because of their lack of scientific
truth?
You spent many years in, well, you've traveled
around the world, but you spent many years
in Lillydale, New York, which is a spirituals
community and your recognition of the similarities
between photography and spiritualism is really
echoed in that they grew up right down the
street from each other with Kodak being right down the street.
Yes.
Yes.
When I began my project at Lillydale, I was a
photographer, I was working as a professional
photographer.
I had studied photography in college, and I had no idea that spiritualism had this very
deep and profound connection with the medium of photography.
I'd like to say that spiritualism is the first
religion to use the new medium of photography
as to make an iconography.
Previously, that had only been done in painting.
And also, the first seances that ever happened
happened in Rochester, New York at a place
called Corinthian Hall that's no longer there,
but it was located literally down the block
from where Kodak's headquarters are.
So there's a synchronicity that the exact
same area and the exact same city introduced
both spiritualism and photography into popular culture, brought it to the masses.
Art has been helping to represent what's going
on inside of an individual, the consciousness,
imagery that we can't always put into words.
And I think that in more the modern era with
photography, the tricky part is that sometimes
people will look at these photographs and just think they look fake.
Spirit photography, one of its most distinctive
qualities is that it represents a thing in
its opposite.
It demonstrates what the mystic is saying is
happening, and it also negates it by making
it seem fake or fraudulent.
Like a lot of the early spirit photographs, they look like double exposures.
Some tables that are flying might look like they're held up by string.
There's an absurdity and a true, they almost
seem like pranks or they come across that
way.
They come across in a very silly, unserious way, yet they reenact the reality that is
being claimed that is actually happening.
And this flickering is something that makes them so interesting.
I think that the art world is now re-looking
at spiritualist art and photography, and that's
been represented in some of the most major
museums and art shows that have recently been
happening.
I think it's about the novelty and also the paradox.
They're almost like they make you meditate on the topic.
And these have been discounted by parapsychologists or even by spiritualists.
A lot of spiritualists are uncomfortable with
the history of spirit photography because
it failed in convincing everybody that these were true images.
It failed proving spirits through photographs.
But I see them as very complicated objects that speak to a lot of the issues at play.
We also don't understand the role that fraud
and deception plays in parapsychology, in
mediumship.
I mean, the whole history is wrought with people who are caught cheating or accused
of cheating or put in situations where they were forced not to cheat.
It speaks to the topic in a very interesting way.
Yeah.
It seems that we as humans are ever searching,
or many humans are ever searching for proof
of the unseen world or the spiritual.
Yes.
Yes.
And these topics are incredibly difficult to prove, as parapsychologists know.
And I think parapsychology is a very unique
science because you're dealing with a phenomena
that is deeply attached to human emotions and
meaning and a subjective reality overlapping
an objective reality.
So, for example, one of my heroes in the whole
history of parapsychology is the medium Eileen
Garrett.
She was a medium herself, but she built a whole foundation to try and scientifically
study her own mediumistic gifts, which she
did not understand and she couldn't classify,
she couldn't explain.
But she also started a press, a literary
press, to also look at it through literature.
And she called for a multidisciplinary approach
to studying these things, and not just with
science, but with art, with literature, looking
at the history of magic, looking at neuroscience,
looking at dream research, kind of using this
multifaceted way to understand this topic
that's very deeply connected to the human experience and the deepest questions that
we have about ourselves.
And yet there have been many parapsychological
scientific studies that have shown that there
definitely is something going on here.
Yes.
And J.B. Ryan statistically proved ESP exists,
but yet it's not acknowledged or it's not
part of, when you talk to somebody about these
topics, the average person would say, well,
science would have proved it if it was true.
There's something, there's still something about it that is unacceptable.
You and I had spoken, and you mentioned how you've talked to scientists who have said,
you know, the criteria for how they're judging
parapsychology evidence is much higher than
how they do in other studies.
Yeah, I just spoke with Mona Sobhani, who's
a neuroscientist, who said that when she was
exploring it, that she found just that, that
the methods used in the research studies of
parapsychology are often even more rigorous than other fields of science.
Right.
So what do we do with that?
And I think that the art that is related to these topics speaks to a mythical reality.
And myth is a way of acknowledging truth in the world that is, it's often defined as
fiction that is true, you know, and myth outlasts science.
Myths last for thousands of years.
Scientific theories only stay around for a few hundred.
So, you know, we need to acknowledge this mythical
reality that is in the art of parapsychology.
And that's kind of the way I look at it.
And we allow literature, you know, I think pretty much materialists would agree that
literature is one of the things humans use to grapple with the complexity of life.
And we acknowledge that there is a truth in it.
And so how does parapsychological material relate to this idea?
And, you know, when I look at the history
of parapsychology, I think of all the iconic
symbols that have come out of it.
You know, like the Ouija board planchette, the bent spoon, the Zener cards, even.
They make the imagination go wild.
Skeptics use them just as much to argue their points as the believers do.
Flying tables, you know, all of these things
that also, too, they make the familiar strange.
They confront us with ideas that reality might
not be exactly as our senses perceive it.
And, you know, in the 19th century, we also
learned that to believe that our senses were
the only way to get knowledge became unscientific.
You know, with the realization that there was
radioactivity, that, you know, electricity,
the way electricity worked, atomic theory, the communication with the telephone or the
radio or the telegraph.
Well, you mentioning that myth has survived for so long that I think it speaks to our
inner selves and those archetypes of who we are.
But just to bring it back to your own photography,
when you were with those mediums, one thing
that struck me when reading your book is that you mentioned that some of the people
who would be in a reading or a sitting or a seance, whatever the term is, that they
would see, for example, maybe ectoplasm or something appear that was physical in the
room.
But yet when it was photographed, it would sometimes be portrayed differently.
Like maybe some of the ones that had the ectoplasm
in there with some images, they looked sort
of cartoonish.
But then the people in the room said that that doesn't seem to really represent what
was happening in that moment in time in reality.
Yeah.
The photographic reality kind of negated it or betrayed it.
And so that's why one of the first people to photograph ectoplasm, Shrek Natsingh, he
actually stopped using photography and started just relying on human testimony.
But yeah, it speaks to this thing like this flickering, this true false thing.
It's almost like a Zen Cohen or something.
And when I say that we don't really understand
how fraud works or even the fraud seems to
be prevalent, I mean, we don't understand how placebo works either.
And that's one of the big mysteries of science is how the placebo works.
And I don't know, I mean, I'm just riffing here, but we really don't understand what
deception and fraud, what the role actually plays.
Carl Jung argued that maybe the natural progression
of any kind of period of psychic study would
be fraud or deception in order to get the attention away from it.
So consensus reality could reign again or
kind of like a restart or a cleansing aspect.
I think that's really interesting.
Yeah.
Well, you mentioned the placebo effect, and
it's something that I've actually looked into
and studied a fair amount.
And it seems that belief plays a significant
role in how a person responds to something,
whether they expect that it will help them or if they expect that it won't help them.
It's usually consistent with what their expectations
are and beliefs are around if it's an inert
substance like some type of pill or some type of experience as well.
And it seems that what we believe is really can indicate how our life functions overall
in general.
Yeah, yeah, definitely.
And in parapsychology, there was even a placebo
experiment trying to bring about ghosts.
It was called the Philip experiment in the 70s.
And it was psychologists who got together and
they say, we're going to invent this ghost
and we're going to sit together.
They made his whole life story.
They would sit together in a circle and they
would concentrate on invoking this fake ghost,
this ghost that they invented, but they started to get very real phenomena.
And it's documented in a book called Conjuring Philip.
Wow.
What do you make of that?
Again, it gets to this, what makes this stuff so interesting?
We don't really understand the role of performance
or acting or reenactment or fraud or deception.
All of these things kind of blur in these practices.
In shamanism, in our culture, all of these connections between the true and the false
are very pulled apart.
But in shamanism, a successful shaman performs
the act, like the successful act is the illusion.
And there wasn't a criteria of true and false
as much, as you see with shamanic healing,
things like psychic surgery.
Well, and meaning seems to also impact a person's
experience as well and how they might either
perceive or maybe even intend for something to occur.
Right.
We don't understand what's being activated
deep inside ourselves when we see an illusion.
But you yourself have been in those spaces and you've been around a lot of mediums and
spiritualists and you've seen ectoplasm up close and personal.
So what is your takeaway from some of those experiences as to what is occurring?
Yeah, it's a very complicated topic within spiritualism, the idea of ectoplasm, which
is this physical substance that's supposed to merge the realms of life and death.
It's a substance that emanates in the seance
room, largely from the bottom of the body
of the medium and takes form, makes materializations, shows images.
And for my book, I spent time with the most controversial medium who's working today,
a man named Kai Muge from Germany.
And he's been studied by parapsychologists such as Stephen Braude.
When I went to his seances, it was like seeing
these vintage photographs jump to life right
before my eyes.
And I asked Kai, why do you do this?
Why do you go around doing these ectoplasmic seances?
And he says, the first reason is for healing,
that there's a healing that comes about just
simply by trying to merge the realms of life and death or this world and the next.
And then he said, the second reason is to get people out of their own heads.
And he said, I'm not trying to prove anything to anybody.
I am just happy if at least they have one thought out of their normal thought pattern
in our seances.
And he's a really fascinating person to talk to.
He documents his own seances.
He has a blog online where you can see images
and videos and all sorts of things that he's
done of his work over the years.
And he and I have talked about the strangeness
and just the absolute bizarre quality of some
of these images.
And he says that there's something in the
bizarreness that is necessary because it gets
to or is able to open up something in the viewer that otherwise can't be accessed.
It seems that some people are looking for more evidence or physical proof.
And others are very happy with maybe the messages
verbally they receive, or maybe their own
communication with, for example, a deceased loved one.
Mm-hmm.
Yeah.
And my book, it's all about spiritualism.
And I have to be careful to say that there's
a lot of disagreement within spiritualism
about whether these practices are really relevant to us anymore.
There are mediums who believe we need to move
on from these darkroom seances and trying
to produce ectoplasm.
And we need to focus on evolving consciousness.
And then they focus very much what you'll see in spiritualism is like what you see in
the popular TV shows, like the Long Island Medium.
It's like what we're doing here today.
We're in a room that's lit, and we're just having a conversation.
That's what a lot of modern mediumship actually is.
But there are people within the movement who
say, no, this has been with us since the very
beginning.
The very first mediumship was physical mediumship,
and that there is something necessary about
going into a darkroom and turning your senses
off and seeing what—and bringing forth evidence
in that way.
So, you know, and spiritualists are just by
nature free thinkers, so that you have a lot
of—and then, you know, all along the way, a lot of different opinions and different
ways of looking at it, even other than those two ways.
I admire your neutrality that you bring to the topic.
Yeah, that was really difficult because there
is, you know, so many people that I love and
respect who are mediums work in very different ways.
Yeah, it's true.
Everybody's got a different style.
And really, I think a lot of them have their own gifts.
Yeah, and they have their own way of doing it.
And also, early on, as I was working with
my project, people would write to me or call
me and say, hey, can you refer me to a medium?
And early on, I used to do it, and then sometimes it didn't work out.
And then there'd be some times where somebody
would have a session with a medium I did not
think was particularly talented, and they would tell me these amazing stories.
And so I started to think, I think maybe
something about human chemistry and also timing
has something to do with why a reading works and why it doesn't.
I myself, I've had a lot of readings, and
some of them, I'll be sitting with the medium
and think, none of this is making sense.
And then I had one reading with a medium who I was particularly impressed by.
And so I booked a reading, and then the
information I got really didn't make sense to me.
But it did make sense five years later, and that was really shocking.
And I guess that's why a lot of mediums record
their readings, so that you have it for posterity.
And I was really amazed.
One of my favorite mediums in Lillydale is a woman named Gretchen Clark.
And she was one of the first mediums who allowed me to photograph her.
And when I went and photographed, I sat in, she allowed me to sit in on readings.
I sat in on one of her readings, and I saw her,
she gave all this information about a horse,
a brother that didn't exist, a property, this, that, tons of rich detail.
And the people sat there and said, no, no, no, no, no.
And then she just closed her eyes and asked again.
And she said, no, that's what I have for you.
And she just left it at that.
And they left kind of confused, and she was fine.
And so, then I followed up with the people.
And like two weeks later, they did all this family research, and they found out
every single thing she said was true.
And it revealed this story about their families that they didn't even know.
And so, when I saw Gretchen, I said, Gretchen,
those people are here for the reading.
Did you know that they went back and they found all this?
And she's like, oh, that's really nice, but I don't need that.
Like, she was so certain.
And she trusted her process and her practice
so much that it didn't matter that I, I mean,
she said it was nice, but it didn't really,
she didn't need that for her to do her work.
And I was really taken with that.
It was, I thought that was very powerful.
It was really interesting to me early on when, because when I started,
I didn't really understand much about any of these topics.
Yeah.
She was so certain of her own abilities
that she didn't really need that validation.
Yeah.
And early on, one of the most surprising things
to me was finding out that you could study
mediumship.
I was just, when I first started, I
thought, oh, people are just born with this.
And then they just do it or, you know, they're
just, and it's no, there are development things
called development courses.
And a very interesting thing I saw was I was at
the Arthur Finley College, which is a learning
center for spiritualists in England.
And people will come all over, all over the
world, not speak the same language and be able
to connect on this way they worked with their consciousness.
And when you see people who don't know each
other, who are from completely different cultures,
talk about a mechanism that's deep at work inside of themselves,
it's hard not to acknowledge the authenticity.
I don't know how you fake that.
And they were able to help each other and teach
each other despite the barriers of culture
and language.
I think what you say about timing and people
connecting with the right person at the right
time or them having their own experiences
can really help with that, the doubting mind.
I've, in my practices with intuition, one of the key tenets is that if you doubt it,
you're going to block it.
And so when people are questioning, I mean, by all means, we need to,
you know, if people are making claims that they are faking, you know, that's something
to acknowledge.
But I think it seems that many people are quite genuine and authentic and that if we
can open our minds to the possibilities that
actually, I think there's even research.
I got to talk to Bernard Bightman, who has
been researching meaningful coincidences and
synchronicities.
And the more that we believe in that and allow
for that and talk about that, the more that
those occurrences actually happen.
Yeah, it's fascinating.
Did you have any synchronicities when you've
been looking into art and parapsychology?
Yeah, I feel like my whole process and my
whole journey with this topic has been a series
of synchronicities and events that led me to where I needed to go.
And it's funny because my first days in
Lilydale, the mediums would say, oh, you know,
you're here for, you know, you'll see, you'll find out or, you know, you'll see.
And like I said, early on, I had no idea.
I didn't even understand how you could be a sane person and still be talking with dead
people.
I just didn't understand it because I had never.
But I was meeting all these wonderful, lovely
people who obviously to me, obvious to me
that they had an authentic practice and that they were called to the work.
And that's one of the stereotypes that is out there, I think, is that anybody who's
involved in mediumship or spiritualism is a fraud who wants to get money off of people.
And I was immediately confronted with that as not being what was happening in Lilydale
and not the reality of the people I was meeting.
You know, I felt like it was spiritual work that they were called to and they weren't
making crazy amounts of money at all.
And another stereotype that my work is about
and all of my interests concerning spiritualism
and parapsychology and art is that there's a stereotype that this is for dumb people
or it's anti-intellectual or you're gullible or something.
But digging into the history, the most amazing
minds of the 19th and 20th century were involved
with these topics.
It's deeply tied to almost every innovation of the late 19th century.
Madame Curie sat in seances and investigated
them, her and her husband Pierre, and she
won the Nobel Prize.
There was a series of Nobel Prize winners you
can find in mathematicians, Thomas Edison,
Abraham Lincoln and his wife held seances.
And these details were written out of many of the histories that I studied from.
And so, I'm really interested in how spiritualism
and mediumship and ESP or psychokinetic energy
relates to innovation and new things that we bring into the world.
It seems to me to be everywhere and that, in
fact, some of the most important intellectuals
find that rational thought only takes them so
far and that they are absolutely confronted
with these topics and need to explore them.
Several innovations and inventions have occurred
with people getting insights through dreams.
Yes.
Yeah.
The whole dream thing is fascinating also.
And the connection to the dream state or that
level of consciousness and how that plays
into all of these topics.
How does art have the ability to tell the truth that science cannot?
Art speaks to the emotional truth that is at work.
And it also helps tell the story of these topics and how they relate to meaning and
they connect with meaning.
They bring in images, right?
Yes.
Yes.
The images help tell the story.
They help tell the truth of the ideas.
They help tell the truth of the experience.
And they help spread the ideas and the interest.
And they create conversation.
They draw people in in a way that scientific study does not.
One of my favorite things about parapsychology
is there's history of colorful characters
and all the really quirky devices, like the cabinets that they build for mediums, like
Houdini's cabinet that he put the medium margarine to test her.
Or like the artist Susan McWilliam in Ireland,
she has a breadth and depth of work all about
the laboratory as kind of similar to the artist's
studio and the blindfolds that are used or
the fingertip perception studies or the boxes
and weights and chains that are put around
medium's feet.
Right.
When you see these devices at work, you see that parapsychology is really, there's an
absurdity to these devices and it's almost
like related to the absurdity of the question,
can we really know these things?
And there's like a playful theatrical element to
parapsychology that you can find understanding
in by looking at the material culture.
Well, and some of those devices do look sort
of strange out of context, but when you really
explore what they were used for and how they
aided a process that maybe they aren't, that's
so strange after all, just like beauty's in the eye of the beholder.
Yeah, yeah.
So I think that the image factory of
parapsychology has inspired a lot of my favorite
artists like Tony Orsler and the artist Brian
Catling, who just, he just passed, but he
was in England.
And Tony Orsler is a media artist here in the
United States and he has a huge collection
of parapsychology material and his art is
very much inspired by all of this, the whole
image factory of how we study these things
and what they say about perception and human
experience and entertainment and illusion.
And I feel that artists really are tuned into
aspects of parapsychology that have kind of
been lost or forgotten or overlooked.
And artists also can create a positive attention
towards these topics, which is very much needed.
I understand why parapsychology hasn't fully
embraced its artistic heritage or it's not
really integrated because art is very interpretive
and subjective and parapsychology has had
to struggle to be taken seriously and to be taken seriously had to be very precise and
very objective and almost cleanse out anything
that seems entertaining or subjective or silly
or it has this demand to be even more buttoned
up than regular science because it's making
such broad claims.
While there are those images that are from experiments, shall we say, or experiences
that people have had through parapsychology,
you've also discovered that there are many
artists who maybe wouldn't consider themselves
to be mediums or even be in the field of
parapsychology who are getting major exhibitions
and who have been active really throughout
art history who are now getting more attention.
There's exciting attention happening for
mediumistic art and visionary art related to
spiritualism and related to the study of parapsychology.
For example, the Swedish artist Hilma Afklint
is now being acknowledged as a pioneer of
abstract painting and she was unknown in her life and was a medium who said that
spirits were physically guiding her hand and
then later she worked in a different way where
they were using her consciousness.
And there was a recently exhibition of her work at the Guggenheim Museum in 2019 that
was the best-selling catalog and the most
attended exhibition the museum has ever had.
Last year at the Venice Biennale Milk of Dreams
exhibition, which is the Venice Biennale is one
of the biggest art events in the world, there was a pavilion of seance photography.
And recently here in Minneapolis, there was the Supernatural America exhibition,
which dealt with all sorts of art about UFO, about mediumship, about magic.
And so there is like a newfound openness and
interest in these topics and especially art
that was made through with the help of spirits
or that the practitioners said was made with
the help of spirits and people are more open or
fascinated or interested in this form of art.
Yeah.
Throughout history and when people experience major loss, transition,
grief, or there's a lot of discomfort going on
in society and culture, people can turn toward
looking to the spiritual realm. And it seems that
that was sort of what was happening around the
turn of the century, going into the 20th
century. And also, with our recent pandemic,
do you think that that was also somehow impacting this occurring?
Yes, I think our culture is definitely in a time of transition. And there's a lot of
anxiety. And also, there's a lot of, you know, we're questioning gender roles,
we're questioning what is truth in science? How do we know the truth in science? How do

I've been working with the sociologist, Jim McLennan. And he, for a number of years,

They created films, audio, a massive, massive,

on today in this interview in a very profound way.
And a lot of it's never been seen before. And
a lot of it was, especially the films were

But Jim came to the realization that he started

a sociological study was a really valid way
